noun.description: A particular level of rank, quality, proficiency, intensity, or value.
examples: sea salt is usually available in coarse or fine grades

noun.description: A mark indicating the quality of a student's work.
examples: I got good grades last semester
just over the crest of a long seven percent grade

noun.description: A variety of cattle produced by crossing with a superior breed.

verb.description: Arrange in or allocate to grades; class or sort.
examples: they are graded according to thickness

verb.description: Give a mark to (a student or a piece of work).
Pass gradually from one level, especially a shade of color, into another.
examples: the sky graded from blue to white on the horizon

verb.description: Reduce (a road) to an easy gradient.

phrases: the crossing at grade of two streets
The total distance of the metro line will be 36.50 km of which 29.15 km will be elevated, 0.65 km at grade and 6.70 km will be underground.
Sharp said she decided to put the new plan forward because it became obvious Vancouver City council will not approve a light rail system built at grade through the city.
This track crossed it at a diamond, one of the last such crossings at grade with streetcars.
Planning requirements mean tall residential buildings have setbacks and open areas at grade, making the streetscape discontinuous and usually unpleasant.
origin: Early 16th century: from French, or from Latin gradus step. Originally used as a unit of measurement of angles (a degree of arc), the term later referred to degrees of merit or quality.
